image.altText: White power drug, sprinkled on reflective surface, with ziplock plastic bag.

props.synopsis: Advocates say since the ACT decriminalised "personal use" amounts of some illicit drugs, the territory has seen a shift toward meaningful harm reduction, but others are calling for those laws to be repealed, saying they are not working as intended.

title.children: ACT 'beginning to see change' two years on from drug decriminalisation

image.altText: A woman with long blonde hair sits on a couch looking down at an image of a smiling young man with short dark hair.

props.synopsis: After Canberra woman Leesa Mountford's son, Josh Clarke, took his own life at 25, she co-founded grassroots support network I Got You — helping to fill a gap with demand for support services skyrocketing in the past two years.

title.children: After Josh took his life, his mum started a support network in his honour

image.altText: Man wearing sunglasses and a dark blue suit and tie.

props.synopsis: Canberra man Josh Fenwick, 29, is found guilty of raping a 16-year-old girl he took home from Civic with her friend after a night out drinking.

title.children: Canberra man found guilty of raping teen as co-accused's charge dismissed

image.altText: A fish hotel made of wood and rocks in the bend of a slow-moving freshwater river.

props.synopsis: This spring offers a critical window to see if man-made "bungalows" installed in rivers can help a struggling fish species. If they work, they could provide a path forward for restoring other battling Australian freshwater fish populations.

title.children: How ecologists turned fish 'hotels' into 'bungalows' to save a species

image.altText: A man and woman sit on a ute with a dog and a load of hay.

props.synopsis: Operating a pub is no mean feat, but try doing it while running a farm at the same time. That is exactly what farmers Karen and Rowan Alcock have done in their town of Bemboka on the New South Wales far south coast.

title.children: Farmers buy local pub to help foster connection in country town

image.altText: Wide shot of men and boys on rocks carrying surfboard down to the beach, one surfboard has Aboriginal flag painted on it

props.synopsis: It started with a surf lesson, but these these Indigenous teens found something far deeper in the ocean.

title.children: How surf lessons helped Indigenous teenagers find a connection to country

image.altText: Netball9

props.synopsis: Before they take the court, the Magnolias strap on knee braces and tie bows in their hair. But don't be deceived, they're playing one of the 'most competitive games', and there may be elbows thrown.

title.children: Knee braces are the norm in this competitive sport adaptation

image.altText: Two men and a woman, who are brothers and sister, smiling.

props.synopsis: Virginia Roberts Giuffre's brothers are calling for the Epstein files, which they believe include videotapes, to be released. One says he knew for years about her allegation against their father.

title.children: 'Known for a long time': Giuffre's brother opens up on rape allegations against father

image.altText: A montage of images including the back of a person and two newspaper clippings, one with a headline about "fondle claims".

props.synopsis: Victims of a paedophile who used children's artwork to hide abuse are suing the Victorian Education Department, alleging his abuse should have been stopped earlier.

title.children: Victims say paedophile teacher groomed them to believe students were his 'wives'

image.altText: Penguins near Casey Station

props.synopsis: A document linked to the arrest of a scientist has raised questions about whether Russia has long-term ambitions to exploit oil resources in Antarctica, where mining is banned indefinitely.

title.children: Russia's interest in Antarctic oil exposed after scientist's arrest

image.altText: People abandon a car on a street flooded by rains caused by Tropical storm Melissa.

props.synopsis: The Category 5 storm is threatening to unleash torrential rain and threatening to cause catastrophic flooding in the northern Caribbean, including Haiti and Jamaica.

title.children: Hurricane Melissa strengthens to Category 5 as it begins lashing Caribbean

image.altText: A woman with a pair of glass at an annual dinner

props.synopsis: The Reserve Bank governor tells a Sydney gathering of economists she and her overseas counterparts are perplexed by what they call "sanguine" financial markets. They question is whether it will "all end in tears".

title.children: 'Might all end in tears': Central bankers watching global markets

image.altText: A man wearing a necklace and a tshirt with of a man's picture printed on it with the words Bring Itay Home Now

props.synopsis: The father of one of the dead hostages still in Gaza says he does not trust Hamas's assurances it is doing all it can to find and return the remains of Israelis.

title.children: Israeli families wait for release of remaining hostages in Gaza

image.altText: A man wearing a navy blue suit stands next to a woman wearing a navy blue dress

props.synopsis: Ten people to go on trial over cyberbullying of French President Emmanuel Macron's wife Brigitte Macron after they allegedly made "malicious" comments online spreading claims she is a man.

title.children: Ten face trial accused of cyberbullying France's first lady Brigitte Macron

image.altText: A render of the west gate tunnel entrance showing a ventilation structure.

props.synopsis: Victoria's emergency services are unprepared for critical incidents in Melbourne's soon-to-be-opened West Gate Tunnel, senior firefighters warn.

title.children: Top firefighters say West Gate Tunnel not safe until checks completed

image.altText: A person in orange and green tracksuit holds an Australian flag with a group of people dressed the same in a full stadium

props.synopsis: In the year 2000, few things would have pushed back the nightly ABC News bulletin. When a wheelchair race did, legendary broadcaster Karen Tighe knew the Paralympics had truly arrived in Australia.

title.children: How a delayed news bulletin changed the Australian Paralympic movement

image.altText: A graphic of a young unidentified girl sitting on a chair, her face down, in a Family Court waiting room.

props.synopsis: Sally's legal battle in the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia may be years long gone, but the trauma of the experience lingers — especially on her eldest child.

title.children: Kids left powerless in 'disgusting custody battles' at Family Court

image.altText: A close-up shot of a woman with brown hair

props.synopsis: Lithuania has drawn up plans to shut its border crossings with Belarus indefinitely, after the capital's airport was repeatedly disrupted by suspected sightings of balloons carrying contraband cigarettes.

title.children: Lithuania vows to shoot down Belarus smuggler balloons disrupting air traffic

image.altText: A large brown bear followed by two small bear cubs walking in a rocky area.

props.synopsis: A record number of fatal attacks has prompted one regional leader to call for more help in dealing with the problem.

title.children: Japan asks army to cull bears after spike in fatal attacks

image.altText: CoDA_libb_SuppWoolloongabbaFlood_20241201_20251027-061646

props.synopsis: Experts say changes by the Queensland government could ease construction costs by removing what the property industry describe as "unnecessary" restrictions, while residents could be left wearing the fallout.

title.children: Flood risk put on residents as flood measures relaxed in housing push

image.altText: A grey storm cloud sits above a truck parked on the side of a road.

props.synopsis: A cool change on Tuesday will provide welcome relief after the extreme heat as thousands remain without power across the state.

title.children: Temperatures plummet across Queensland after record-breaking heat

image.altText: Man smiles off to the side.

props.synopsis: Former California governor Arnold Schwarzenegger has expressed concern over the "crazy gerrymandering" that is taking place across the US.

title.children: 'Spreading like wildfire': Schwarzenegger criticises gerrymandering surge

image.altText: A WA Police officer holds a small black metal detector wand.

props.synopsis: Tasmania Police confirms despite five knife-detecting wands being available, none were being used by officers in Hobart on the night of an alleged stabbing murder.

title.children: Knife-detecting wands not used by police on night of fatal Hobart stabbing

image.altText: A man close camera with fingers touching tips

props.synopsis: In his 2025 Boyer Lecture, former deputy prime minister John Anderson reflects on democracy and the end of the liberal global order.

title.children: The liberal global order that has defined our age is coming to an end

image.altText: a red missile head poking out from underneath a sheet while two workers in white lab outfits work on the missile

props.synopsis: Russia says the 9M730 Burevestnik "Storm Petrel" is "invincible" to current and future missile defences, with an almost unlimited range and unpredictable flight path.

title.children: Russian missile test not 'appropriate', Trump tells Putin

image.altText: a man in a suit with the shirt and blazer buttons undone

props.synopsis: A Sydney MP has told a gay magazine about his battle with post-traumatic stress disorder and how he turned to exercise and medical cannabis to manage it.

title.children: Alex Greenwich opens up on abuse after Mark Latham's graphic post

image.altText: A hand holding a phone with the BOM website

props.synopsis: In a week of wild weather across the country, the Bureau of Meteorology's new website missed the mark.

title.children: Bureau of Meteorology defends unpopular new weather website

image.altText: Bright red sunset over Brisbane

props.synopsis: More than 25,000 people are without power after south-east Queensland has been hit by storms, smoke, fires and winds.

title.children: Tens of thousands to be without power overnight in south-east Queensland

image.altText: Hannah sitting in the sun smiling with a drink in hand.

props.synopsis: Loved ones of Victorian woman Hannah McGuire looked on with shock as a prosecutor told the Supreme Court of her 2024 murder and the events leading up to it.

title.children: Courtroom filled with disgust for Hannah McGuire's killer, Lachlan Young

image.altText: A basket lift outside the Louvre museum.

props.synopsis: What do we know about the investigation into the jewel heist at the Louvre and what are some of the possible consequences?

title.children: Could the theft of gold and jewels from the Louvre have a silver lining?

image.altText: peg stands against brick wall holding her phone

props.synopsis: Data from the latest HILDA survey indicate socialising rates have dropped over the past two decades, and, more recently, have not returned to pre-COVID frequency.

title.children: We are socialising less and loneliness is rising. Here is what can help

image.altText: Firefighter sprays white substance from hose.

props.synopsis: The warning for a bushfire in northern New South Wales has been downgraded after it threatened to reach Emergency Warning level amid deteriorating weather conditions on Monday afternoon.

title.children: Firefighters halt spread of bushfire fanned by hot winds

image.altText: Donald Trump leans over and listens to Hun Manet as they sit in chairs in front of a peace sign.

props.synopsis: The US president, who is on a lightning tour of South-East Asia this week, casts a long shadow in the region. But even as he signs deals, nations are contemplating a future without him.

title.children: Trump's flashy 'peace agreement' sparks wariness in South-East Asia

image.altText: Man and policeman

props.synopsis: The family of a 43-year-old one-punch attack victim told his killer their lives "have been shattered beyond recognition" during an emotional Queensland court hearing.

title.children: One-punch killer Joshua Berrigan sentenced to 10 years' jail

image.altText: A man wearing a dark shirt stands outside a courthouse

props.synopsis: Photos and videos shown to a Victorian court capture a racially charged speech given by Thomas Sewell before he leads a group of 30 masked men through Ballarat.

title.children: Neo-Nazi leader Thomas Sewell claims Ballarat rally was political
